com.joliciel.talismane.machineLearning.features

Class AbstractFeature<T,Y>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.joliciel.talismane.machineLearning.features.AbstractFeature<T,Y>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Feature<T,Y>, java.lang.Comparable<Feature<T,?>>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    AbstractCachableFeature, AbstractFeatureParser.RootWrapper, AbstractLanguageDetectorFeature, AddressFunctionBuffer, AddressFunctionDep, AddressFunctionHead, AddressFunctionLDep, AddressFunctionOffset, AddressFunctionRDep, AddressFunctionSequence, AddressFunctionStack, AncestorSearchFeature, BackwardSearchFeature, BetweenCountIf, BooleanLiteralFeature, DependencyCountIf, DependencyLabelFeature, DependencySearchFeature, DistanceFeature, DoubleLiteralFeature, ForwardSearchFeature, ImplicitAddressFeature, IntegerLiteralFeature, IntegerLiteralFeatureWrapper, IntegerToDoubleFeature, PosTaggedTokenAddressFunctionWrapper, StackSearchFeature, StringLiteralFeature, TokenSearchFeature, ValencyByLabelFeature, ValencyFeature

    public abstract class AbstractFeature<T,Y>
extends java.lang.Object
implements Feature<T,Y>, java.lang.Comparable<Feature<T,?>>
    An Abstract base class for features, basically defining feature equality.
    Author:
    Assaf Urieli

      • getCollectionName

        public java.lang.String getCollectionName()
        Description copied from interface: Feature
        A single feature descriptor can result in the generation of multiple features (e.g. in the case where it refers to a range of indexes). The collection name groups all these features under one name - that of the feature descriptor. It can used, for example, for measuring the performance of the entire collection of features together.
        Specified by:
        getCollectionName in interface Feature<T,Y>
